div.head: AFTER DENISHWAI.
div.p: The Court has given its decision, and four of the leaders of the savage mob which committed a brutal and unprovoked attack on British officers will within the next few hours have expiated their crime with their lives. Various terms of imprisonment have been inflicted on the other criminals, and there is every reason to believe that their punishment is thoroughly deserved. Their crime was atrociously brutal and cowardly. Helpless men were beaten, insulted, rob, beat, and threatened with death or torture. Their assailants made it perfectly clear by their conduct that they were actuated, not by a mistaken impression that the victims of their violence had set a "girn" on fire, but by the determination to kill and maltreat any person whom they found shooting pigeons near their village. The pigeons were wild, and could not be said to be the property of any individual, but such arguments were unlikely to appeal to a savage mob of criminal villagers.

We must at the same time, point out in common fairness to the Egyptians that the people of Denishwai are by no means typical of the population of the Delta. Europeans new to the country must not allow themselves to be prejudiced against the fellah by the misconduct of an exceptionally criminal village. We readily admit that the great majority of Egyptian peasants are sober, peaceful, and industrious cultivators, and we hope that the misconduct of a village or a district will not injure the reputation of the whole community in the minds of those who have been horrified by the outbreak of savagery which cost the British Army one of its most promising officers.

Finally, we should like to express our admiration of the conduct of the British officers, which was worthy of the best traditions of the Army. Major Pine-Coffin, who was in command of the party, did all that was in his power to quiet the villagers, and in his desire to prevent a conflict deprived himself and his companions of the means of reesistance to an attack which he had hoped to avert. Capt. Bostock's promptitude in warning the camp also deserves mention, and the natives of the whole district have testified to the discipline and forbearance of the Mounted Infantry under great provocation. We have lost a gallant and distinguised officer, but the self-restraint and forbearance shown on this tragic occasion adds to the honour of the British Army.

div.head: THE CONGO QUESTION
div.p: The official correspondence concerning the affairs of the Congo Free State seems to show that Sir Edward Greyis thorough in his determination that the Free State Government shall not be permitted to snap the fingers of irresponsibility at the opinion of all right-minded men as to its discharge of the functions entrusted to it by Europe. The correspondence ends before the date of the open letter of King Leopold, with the amazing assertion of his own "indivisible rights"; but the fact of the subsequent publication of the challenge to public opinion renders Sir Edward Grey's dispatches all the more important as an indication of the intentions of the British Government. The Foreign Secretary is struck by the inadequate nature of the reforms recommended by the Commission of Inquiry, which are far from realising that "large measure of reform" which he postulates as indispensable. We observe, too, that the scheme of the Belgian Reform Commissioners is severely criticised by N. Cattier, the Belgian Professor of Colonial Jurisprudence. Altogether, it would be well for King Leopold and his agents to be wise in time, or they may find that his "indivisible rights" are susceptible of impartial consideration by the signatory Powers of the Berlin Act.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
Cattle Plague.
div.p: Bovine typhus has broken out at Tahta.

div.head: Bubonic Plague
div.p: Today's bulletin records a case and two recoveries at Samalout, and a recovery at Port Said.

div.head: The Brindisi Mail
div.p: The mail from Europe, via Brindisi and Port Said, will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 4:30 p.m. today.

div.head: San Stefano Casino.
div.p: A grand vocal and instrumental concert will be given at the Casino tomorrow afternoon. We are informed that the first children’s ball of the season will take place on Friday at 5 p.m.

div.head: British Museum.
div.p: The Principal Trustees of the British Museum have appointed Mr. Herbert A. Grueber, Keeper of Coins and Medals, on the retirement of Dr. Barclay V. Head. Mr. Grueber is the Hon. Treasurer of the Egyptian Exploration Fund.

div.head: Savoy, Port Said.
div.p: Among the latest arrival at the Savoy, Port Said, we notice Johnson Pacha, Mr. Seymour, Mr. Furnier, Mr. and Miss Sheldon Amos, Rev. and Mrs. Sydney Smith, M. Martin de la Tour, Major Lee Stack, M. and Mile Saint Plancat, M and Mme Chassinat, Mr.Widal, Mr. Vayssié, Mr. H. B. Greville, Hon. Littleton, Mr. Edward Crewe, M. Pierre Lacan, Mr. Owen R. Lewis, Mr. Fraser, M. and Mme Paul Oziol, Mr. Buttler, Mr. John Lawrence, Major Herbert, Mr. Hood, Mr Babb, Mr. Sore, Blattner Bey.

div.head: Deceptive Britain.
div.p: The Berlin "Post" publishes a statement to the effet that the British Government proposes to construct a railway from Port Said to India. The line would traverse Arabia, touch the Lower Euphrates at Koweit and connect with the line across Soouthern Persia and Afghanistan. The "Post" infers that this scheme is the real eplanation of the value Great Britain attaches to the port of Akabah, and of her hostility to the German proposal to make Koweit the terminus of the Bagdad railway.

div.head: Exciting Incident at Bulkeley
div.p: On Monday morning, Mr. H. Otway Smithers (of the Bedfordshire Regiment), who has been wintering in Egypt, recovering from the effects of enteric contracted in the South African campaign, was proceeding from Church road, Bulkeley, towards Stanley Bay, when his attention was attracted by the screams of a lady and two children sitting helplessly in a hired carriage and being conveyed down Mr. Ruffer’s Hill by a pair of horses entirely without control, for there was no driver on the box. Mr. Smithers ran after the runaways and, scrambling into the carriage, reached the driver’s vacant box and managed to catch hold of the reins. It was not before the bottom of the hill was reached that Mr. Smithers was able to stop the horses. He then drove back to Church road corner and found the - "arbaghi”—an abject helpless creature,— waiting, stricken with terror at what might have happened. Mr. Smithers rated him sound-ly in good English and consoled the lady and the Children. The lady thanked the gallant officer heartily for his prompt assistance

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinons expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- this discussion.

div.head: PRIMARY EDUCATION EXAMINATION.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"

Sir,—We, the candidates of the Primary Education Certificate, have the honour to ask you to join our cry to the Ministry of Public instruction for ordering the party, which is concerned in putting the marks of the examination papers of the dictation, to take notice of the many errors in the dictation given to us.

These errors, however, were erroneously written not because of their difficulty, but because of our mishearing these words from the dictators who, on the other hand, had eaten up many letters and syllables.

Besides, their mode of dictating was quite different from that which we were accustomed to by our Egyptian teachers who taught us that language; and that was due to the fact that they were in a great hurry.

At last, we hope from you to deign and write our complaint on your newspaper "The Egyptian Gazette." Your opinion, however, will not fail in strengthening our demand. We hope again to accept our great thanks.
The Condidates.

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier, DE "L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
div.p: Le Supplement Commercial et Financier de l'"Egyptian Gazette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de facon a pouvoir etre expedie par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues completes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marche des valeurs' les dernieres statistiques jusqu'a la veille de sa publication des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des depeches officielles envoyees a la Liverpool Cotton Association etc. etc.
L'abonnement pour une annee en Egypte coute q L.E. y compris les frais de poste; pour l'etranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.

div.head: RUSSIAN REVOLUTION.
PROPAGANDA IN ARMY PROGRESSING.
BATOUM GARRISON REVOLTS.
div.p: The revolutionary propaganda is progressing in the Russian Army: the Guards Regiments here and at Krasnoe-Selo are affected. Many arrests have been made.
A revolt amongst the garrison has occurred at Batoum. The Cossacks are surrounding the mutineers; the inhabitants are in a state of panic. (Reuter)

A Council, to meet at Peterhof, will tomorrow discuss the question of constituting a Monroutseff Parliamentary Ministry, keeping only the present Ministers of War, Marine, and Foreign Affairs. (Havas)

div.head: NATAL REBELLION
REBELS OCCUPY POLICE STATION.
div.p: The natives in the vicinity of the Insuizi and Noodsberg police station have rebelled and occupied the former. (Reuter)

div.head: DISTURBED BAGDAD.
REPRESENTATIONS TO THE PORTE.
div.p: Sir Nicholas O'Conor has made vigorous representations to the Porte with reference to the disturbed condition of the vilayets of Bagdad and Basra and the frequent murders of British subjects.
The Turkish Commission has been ordered to proceed to Bagdad in order to make investigations. (Reuter)

div.head: BRITAIN AND GERMANY.
THE CONSEQUENCES OF WAR.
div.p: Doctor Barth, a member of the Reichstag, emphasizes the consequences of a war between Great Britain and Germany: neither, he said, would be a penny better off, but the whole of Europe would suffer enormous loss, and America would become the leader of the world. (Reuter)

div.head: MILLIONAIRE COMMITS MURDER.
LOVE AND JEALOUSY.
div.p: An immense sensation has been caused here by the millionaire Harry Thaw, who fired and killed an eminent and wealthy architect named Mr. Stanford White at Madison Square Garden Theatre. The deed has been ascribed to jealousy. Mr. Thaw lately married a beautiful chorus girl whom Mr. White has previously known. Both Thaw and his wife have been arrested. (Reuter)

div.head: EDUCATION BILL
OPPOSITION AMENDMENT REJECTED.
div.p: The debate on Clause 4 of the Education Bill has developed strong opposition on all sides, including some Ministerialists. (Reuter)
An important Opposition amendment to Clause 4 of the Education Bill, making the clauses mandatory, was rejected by 340 votes to 237. (Reuter)

div.head: UNIONISTS AND FISCAL REFORM.
div.p: Mr. Chamberlain, speaking at the inaugural dinner of the 1900 Club, outlined the Unionist policy, in the forefront of which; he said, stood Fiscal Reform, to which all Unionists were pledged. (Reuter)

div.head: GERMAN EDITORS AT MANSION HOUSE.
div.p: The Lord Mayor entertained the German editors at luncheon at the Mansion House. (Reuter)

div.head: HOME CRICKET.
div.p: Cricket. Derby: Notts beat Derbyshire by 10 wickets. (Reuter)

div.head: DEATH SENTENCE
VERDICT IN DENISHWAI CASE.
DEATH PENALTY FOR FOUR LEADERS.
EXECUTION AT DENISHWAI.
div.p: (From our Special Correspondent)
Shibin el Kom, Wednesday.
The verdict of the special tribunal constituted to try the accused in the fatal affray with British officers at Denishwai delivered its judgment this morning.
Sentence of death was passed on the following four prisoners.-
Hassan Mahfouz(11)
Youssef Hassan-Salim (14)
Said Issa Salim (25)
Mohamed Darwish Zahran (48)

Mohamed Abdel Nebi Moazzin(19) and Mohamed Abd Alal Ali Mahfouz(24) were sentenced to penal servitude for life, and Ahmend Mohamed Assissi (13) to fifteen years imprisonment. Six of the others were sentenced to seven years' imprisonment, three to one year and to receive fifty lashes at Denishwai, and five to receive fifty lashes. The rest were acquitted.
The execution will take place at Denishwai tomorrow afternoon at 2 o'clock.

When the Court reassembled this morning Ibrahim Bey Helbawi, counsel for the prosecution, continued his address. The fire in the tibn floor, said counsel, could not have been caused by the officer’s gun. as was amply demonstrated by the evidence, but was started by the natives, who, by nature, were capable of any crime. On the following day, when the authorities were forming a cordon round the village, a woman began to shout that a fire was burning in a "girn" and this second fire was extinguished as quickly as the first. This was also caused by the natives and, said counsel, was done in order to attract the attention of those forming the cordon and afford the villagers, who were guilty of the attack, time to run away. The accused were revengeful. He could not say why. Was it becasue the officers were English or for other reasons? The villagers were, however, as he said before capable of any crime. Even supposing that the fire was caused by the officers, it must be remembered that they gave up their guns. Why should the attack continue? The officers denied having caused the fire. In giving evidence the officers had sworn to speak the exact truth and he believed them whe they said that the four wounded persons were not shot by them.

div.head: The Onbashi's Role
div.p: Referring to the onbashi of police who accompanied them, counsel said that his evidence was in agreement with the prisoners. According to him, one of the officers fired at the natives when they seized Lieut. Porter’s gun. They did not call for evidence from the onbashi of police in the first instance, as they did not wish to put forward the man as an example of the shortcomings of the Egyptian police. They would rather conceal the fact that the police were unintelligent and incapable. Counsel for accused desired the evidence of the onbashi and the prosecution were quite willing for him to be called. The evidence was as the Court had already heard. The onbashi denied meeting any one on the road when he left the officers in order to call the omdeh. He passed the house of Hassan Mahfouz and it could not be determined that he saw nobody; but he denied seeing anyone and instead of going to see the omdeh, he went off to take lunch with Gabr Zohran. He was also asked what took place during the attack and he said that the natives and officers were beating and firing at each other. But he knew nothing. He had fallen from his horse and became frightened. He first stated that the officers fired at the natives and said later that he did know if this was the case. He also said when telephoning to the markezz that the natives fired, but even the officers did not say that they did so, so that his evidence was obviously false.

div.head: Accidental Discharge of Gun.
div.p: It was asserted that the woman who was wounded was shot by the officers, but ocunsel was convinced that she was shot when the gun was being wrested from Lieut. Porter. The medical report showed that the sheikh of the ghaffirs received his wounds in the knee from a gun about 20 ins. away and that the woman was about 1 metre away, while the officer was surrounded by people, and this showed that the gun went off when it was being taken away from the officer. All four persons received the shots from the same gun in their legs, this showing that the gun was not fired purposely. This was in accordance with the statements of the officers. The guns were given up and why did the natives continue the attack except with the intention of doing wilful harm? If the officers had known Arabic they would have had far more evidence to present. On account of the interpretation of the officers evidence the audience did not realise the extreme gravity of their assertions, but counsel was in possession of the full details and know exactly how it took place. The officers were disarmed and ran away, not making any stand against the natives. The were beaten and Major Pine-Coffin fell senseless three times.

div.head: Wanted to kill them.
div.p: The strokes were nearly all about the head as if it had been so arranged, and from this it might be inferred that they intended to kill the officers. When Major Pine-Coffin tell the people still continued to attack the officers. "What did they want? They wanted to kill them.” When they arrived at the carriages the natives did not let the officers go. The arbagi tried to drive away, but was struck on the head by a nabout. The men were using nabouts and the women throwing bricks and stones. The officers were dragged back towards the village and the natives continued their attempts to kill them. They had tibn; placed all round the officers with which to burn them. It appeared, however, that one of the accused persuaded them to abandon their terrible design. They tortured them for an hour. When a quarrel arises both parties usually exchange blows; but in this case only one side attacked. The officers did not even curse the villagers! Two of the officers went ahead for help and three remained at the mercy of an ignorantt and savage crowd. Capt. Ball was struck and afterwards ran on for five kilometres to Sersina, which he reached about two o’clock or half past. The thermometer stood at 42°C.

div.head: Captain Bull's Death
div.p: Capt. Bull was not sufficiently conscious to keep to the road and he fell in a field, about 7 metres from the main road. Capt. Bostock swam across the canal, fully clothed, in order to get to the camp. From the steps taken by the officers it was easy to believe that they thought the natives intended to kill them. The aggression of the people was not forcibly resisted by the officers. This was the exact truth. Even those who were most prejudiced, either from ignorance or from "national" feeling doubted the correctness of their prejudice in this case when they wrote to the Officer in Command of the Army of Occupation thanking Capt. Bostock for having reported the death of Capt. Bull in accordance with the facts. The correspondents of whom he spoke did not even believe what they wrote in their papers, and had later expressed in other papers their belief that the officers were blameless.

div.head: Premeditation.
div.p: The truth was self-evident. "Did the people previously intend to kill the officers or did they suddenly conceive the idea after the attack had commenced? I believe that it was previous intention—even before the officers arrived at the village.” He believed the people intended to kill the officers in the event of their coming near the village to shoot pigeons. Counsel believed Hassan Mahfouz (No. 11); not only to have taken part in the attaock, but to have been the leader. He denied participation but the event took place opposite his house.
The Court then rose for an intervan of a quarter of an hour.

Counsel; continuing, said that from article 297 and note 8, page 414 of the Code, “intention to kill" can be constituted by preparing arms, uttering threats, showing hatred and anger in consequence of previous events. The accused were therefore guilty of premeditation. In note 15 it is laid down that the intent to kill may be formed from a past event. It is difficult to say whether all the accused had previous intention to kill but there could be no doubt of the intentions of the leaders. The fact, however, that they supported the leaders constituted, by law, premeditated murder. As regards the officers who escaped, it was attempted murder. Capt. Bull was murdered and the accused are responsible for his death. It was stated in the first medical report, which was made by the Markas doctor and Capt. Bostock, that death was due to concussion of the brain aggravated by sunstroke. The accused refused to believe this report and it was afterwards demanded that the body of Capt. Bull should be exhumed for the purposes of an autopsy. The second report by Dr. Nolan confirmed the first. The sunstroke, said counsel, was caused by the attack as much as the concussion.

Hassan Mahfouz(11), Ahmen Mohamed el Sissi(13), Youssef Hussein Salem(34), Mohamed Abdel Nebi el Moazin(19), Ahmed Abdel Aal Mahfouz(24), Said Issa Salem (25), and Mohamed Darweesh Zohran(48) were the leaders of the crowd. In the house of No. 48 two guns and other articles belonging to the officers were found.
Counsel then enumerated all the participants in the attack.

div.head: Conduct of Officers.
div.p: In concluding, Ibrahim Bey Helbawi said that the British officers had given proof of their fine character. They might have killed people to defend themselves, bu they desisted to preserve the honour of their nation. These five officers had seen military service. Major Pine-Coffin had distinguished himself in the Transvaal; he bore a medal. He had receieved from the officer in command of the Army of Occupation details concerning all the officers. According to any criminal code the accused might be sentenced; including the Moslem law. The tribunal woul dbe fulfilling its duty if it condemned to death seven of the accused whom he had named.
This concluded counsel's eloquent address; which had lasted three hours and a quarter.

div.head: The Defence.
div.p: Mohamed Bey Youssef, first counsel for the defence, then pleaded. He thanked God that no outrage against the Army of Occupation had taken place with the exception of one at Galioubieh and the attack which had recently taken place at Denishwai. The outrage, the work of ignorant and savage people, inhabiting a criminal district, would, it was to be hoped, make no change in the relations of the British Army towards them. Major Pine-Coffin had said that the natives were always friendly to him. Counsel for the defence were very grateful for the liberty which the Court allowed them. As for premeditation, it was in no way established, and no one could say that the poeple of Denishwai bore malice against the Army of Occupation.

After giving a resume o the occurrence counsel said that Hassan Mahfouz (11) had warned the party through their guide when they were going to shoot. They were not attacked because the people intended to do them harm but probably because they were shooting near the village. He could not say that shooting pigeons justified murder. The reason of the attack was the firing of the tibn and the wounding of a woman. Mohamed Abd el Nebi, the owner of the "girn," saw that the officer had a gun in his hand and he thought he saw fire coming from its mouth. A man who saw his "girn" burnt and his wife shot would not feel particularly grateful. The tree officers who came to assist their colleague fired in his defence and the case then became graver. The policeman said in giving evidence that the officers fired. He could not believe that the gun went off after the people took it becasue Lieut. Porter said that he had put it at "safety" and the people did not know how to cock it. At any rate, if one rifle went off accidentally and the others did not, and he believed that the officers had fired and inflicted injuries on four persons. The natives could not take the rifles and fire them themselves. As regards premeditation, the principal witness wsa Ahmed Bey Habib. The fire could not have been taken as a signal for an attack. Could it be thought that it would take 3,300 people, the number of inhabitants of the village, to kill five men? It was the custom of the fellaheen to form a crowd. If they intended to kill the officers, who could have prevented them? He asked for the release of the accused.

div.head: Medical Evidence.
div.p: The Court rose for an internal of three hours, and on resuming Dr. Nolan was called as Ahmed Bey Loutfi wished to hear his statement as the condition of the four wounded fellaheen because he did not believe that they had all been hurt by one shot. Dr. Nolan was of the opinion that all were wounded by one shot and that it was quite possible fora single charge to inflict the injuries.

Ahmed Bey Loutfithen spoke. After regretting the occurrence of this incident when Lord Cromer had just alluded to the tranquility of Menoufieh, he said he wished to refer to three points: first, a motive for the crime; secondly, the trial according to the code of law, and thirdly, the amount of responsibility chargeable to the accused. The crime was caused by the fire and the excitement arose on the spot and at the moment. Mohamed Abd el Nebi believed the fire to be due to the shooting, but it was now known that it was not due to the officers. After taking the guns from the officers, the natives behaved shamefully, but there was no evidence of previous intention to kill. As regards to his second point, the Court must give judgment according to the Egyptian Code. As regards to the third, it was evident from the medical report that the blows were not sufficient to cause death, which was due to sunstroke. Had the occurrence taken place when the heat of the sun was less powerful it is probable that death would not have occurred.

div.head: Plea of Insanity.
div.p: He had full confidence in the justice of the tribunal, and he would ask the Court to find that Abd el Nebi Mahfouz was insane and not responsible for his actions. For El Gubashi(15), Gubali Ali Salem(40), Mohamed Ahmed Assissi(42), Abd el Daim (46), Ali Ali Montassib(49), Mohamed Ali Tonkar (47), all of whom had been identified, he demanded justice. As for Mohamed Darweesh Zohran (48) and Youssef Hassan Salem, he coul dbut appeal for mercy in their case, and mercy was above even justice.

Ismain Bey Assem then pleaded. He said that there was no previous intention but that the event occurred through a misunderstanding. He could but ask that the judgment would be given according to Egyptian law.

div.head: EGYPTIAN EXHIBITS WANTED.
INTERNATIONAL EXHIBITION IN NEW ZEALAND.
div.p: In a letter from Christchurch, N.Z., to H.B.M.'s Consul at Cairo, directing his attention to the New Zealand International Exhibition, which is to open in November, 1906, and. continue until April, 1907, the Executive Commissioner states that he is derirous of securing Egyptian representation.

The Cairo display at the Chicago Fair was generally admitted to be a popular and interesting display, and he says he is derious of securing the interest of some enterprising firm or firms to have their goods shown at the exhibition or even take out selling rights for those peculiarly novel Egyptian bazaar nic-nacs.

The Executive Commissioner adds: "The five Continents are well represented, but that of North Africa, I regret to say, has not yet applied for space. Any enterprising Cairo firm who deal in scarabs, perfumes, attar of roses, Palestine goods, narghilis, hookahs, Egyptian cigarettes, Arabian curios, antlers of big game, Abyssinian skin rugs, Turkish delight, or articles of local interest, would, I think, find an almost open field for their goods and a prospect of fair remuneration at this exhibition.

"I am prepared to reserve space for any such firms, but as the time is drawing near it is too late to correspond with them direct. Great Britain is paramount in New Zealand trade but a variety of Eastern goods to the people of this country is unique to any Egyptian firm, as fully 2,000,000 visitors are expected to be present.

"Exhibits, not goods for sale, are charged freight on the outward trip only if consigned to Messrs. Shaw, Sevile and Coy., or the Union Steamship Coy. Space is 2s. per sq. foot, flooring and light free; selling rights entail a payment of a small royalty to the executive for the concession. Exhibits may be landed direct from the steamer to the exhibition at a cost of 8s, 6d. per ton."

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS.
div.p: The following are the prinicpal decisions of Monday's Council of Ministers: -
1. Approbation of certain modifications of the law relating to cruelty of animals.
2. Alteration of the alignment of the Sharia Abbas, Mansourah.

3. The following are declared of public utility: The unlargement of the State railway station at Mansourah. Construction of a junction between the El Semata and El Ghilassi canal, Keneh MArkas. Construction of a building for the Irrigation Service at Edfou. Appropriation of land necessary for the enlargement of the discharges and sinks attached to the Zifta abattoir, etc. Establish of a new cemetery in Gharbieh.

4. Approbation of the replacement per interim of the Minister of Public Works and Public Instruction by Mohamed Public Works, Minister of War, and of Ibrahim Negib Pacha, Under Secretary of State to the Ministry of the Interior, by Ismail Pacha Sabri, under Secretary of State to the Ministry of the Justice.

div.head: DEMENTI
div.p: We notice in "L'Egypte" of 26th instant a paragraph to the effect that Mr. Geo. Lewis, acting editory of the "Egyptian Morning News," has resigned that position owing to his numerous occupations. We are requested to formally contradict this statement, which is totally unfounded.

Mr. Lewis has, we understand, resigned on a question of principle, finding himself entirely at variance with the Aglophobe articles which appeared in "L'Egypte" on the 23rd and 24th instant in connection with the Denishwai affair, and it is only just that the truth shoul dbe known as there has been a very evident attempt to suppress it.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman s.s. Falernian sailed from Liverpool on Sunday for Gibraltar, Malta, and Alexandria.
The Ellerman s.s. City of Venice arrived at Liverpool yesterday morning.

div.head: BELLA VISTA HOTEL
div.p: This excellent hotel, which includes also a hydropathic establishment, is situated in the healthiest part of modern Jaffa, close to the sea, and commands a magnificent view of the old town. It supplies every home comfort, has a large salon and airy bedrooms, promenade, and a cuisine suited to all tastes. It is within easy walking distance of the station and quay. Moderate charges.

The Hydropathic Department, which is furnished with all necessary baths and electrical apparatus, is under the care of a skillful diplomed physician, whose effacious treatments have already rendered invaluable help to many sufferers.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
SERVICE DE RECETTES
div.p: La President de la Commission Municipale a l'honneur de prevenir Messieurs les propietaires d'immenbles batis que, en execution du Decret du 13 Mars 1884, les elections des membres appeles a former les Commisions d'evaluations et le Conseil de Revision, auront line de 10 b. du matin a 4 h. dur soir aux endroits et sux jours indiques ci spres, pour chaque kiem dans les formes etablies par lea reglements.

La duree du mandat des membres des Commissions d'evaluations et du Conseil de revision fixee a deux anneas par l'art 6 du Decret, commencera le ler Aout 1906 Nul ne peut etre electeur et n'est eligible que dans le quartier ou il est proprietaire. Chaque electeur doit elire douze proprietaries a son choix sans distinction de nationalite.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS
EXTRACTS FROM THE HOME PAPERS
The Denishwai Affair.
div.p: The spread of the Pan Islamic agitation must be giving Lord Cromer no little anxiety. The old Turks covet a return of the happy times when they could plunder the public revenue, and as British control is incompatible with that restoration, the clique of sordid conspirators strain every endeavour to get rid of it by one method or another. The Pan-Islamic movement is accordingly enlisted for the purpose, as the readiest means of drawing all Mohamedans together against the Christian community. The Sultan was, no doubt, Chiefly encouraged by this got-up religious fermentation to tend troops across the Turco-Egyptian frontier, hoping no donbt, that Mukhtar Pasha, his agent at Cairo, would help the armed enterprise by covertly preaching sedition. But when strong British reinforcements arrived, the plot collapsed, and there is just a possibility that the outrage near Tantah was an after consequence of the previous unrest.

div.head: Griding the Denominationalists.
div.p: “Four-fifths of the occupants of the Front Bench declared before, daring, and after the electoral campaign that Free Trade and Chinese slavery were the dominant issues. Free Trade is not for the moment a problem. And as to Chinese slavery, we all know what has happened. Those who were "slaves” before have been slaves—barring a dozen—since Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman became Premier. No one, however, can pretend that the Free Trade and Anti Chinese electors gave any sort of mandate to any Ministers to grind the faces of Anglicans, Roman Catholics, and Jews.” (Telegraph.”)

div.head: Shipping Losses in War-time.
div.p: It is understood that, at the conclusion of the naval maneuvres, a Commission will be appointed by the Government, with a view to examining into the question of indemnifying the shipping industry, out of the national Exchequer, for losses incurred in time of war. Mr. Henry Wilding, the chairman of the Anglo-American shipping combine, is likely to be suggested as president of this Commission. ("Standard.")

div.head: Europeans in the Congo.
div.p: Colonisation is only a benefit to the people if the colonisers are at the same time civilisers. Now in the Belgian Congo the European e'ement does not civilise. It does not even colonise. It exploits. And it is an intolerable situation to which the reforms announced ought to put an end. ("La Petit Parisien.")

div.head: "Fearing the Light"
div.p: The Congo Government refused to publish the full report of the proceedings before the Inquiry Commission, urging that there is no precept of international law obliging them to do so. In honour, the Congo Government would be clearly bound to publish the full report. The fact that they prefer to sacrifice honour rather than publish it is striking evidence of the gravity of the case disclosed to the Commission. It makes more clear than ever the duty of Europe to enforce the guarantees for good government, that induced the Powers to sanction the founding of the Congo Free State. (“Daily News.”)

div.head: A Polygamous Suggestion.
div.p: "The suggestion," says Saturday's "Daily Telegraph," "that abatement of income tax on £50 should be allowed a man for each child, and on £100 for each wife, is interesting." But the original suggestion was not quite so interesting as all that. ("The Observer.")

div.head: German Editors in London.
div.p: The first entertainment of the German editors on reaching London will be given at His Majesty’s Theatre, where our distinguished visitors will witness a performance of “Colonel Newcome.”__ We can only express our sorrow that there is not sufficient time for Mr. Tree to present the play in German. As a school-boy remarked in our hearing yesterday, with that veracity distinctive of English schoolboys; “German would adsum life to the comedy.” His head was smacked, but he smiled loudly for many, many minutes. (“Westminster G zette.”)

div.head: The Modern Novel.
div.p: The main reflection to which one is brought by looking over modern novels is that the novel is a passing form; it has had its day and must cease. It has been overdone and cheapened until it is difficult to take even the finest novels with seriousness. The external novel, the novel that lacks brooding and profundity of truth and force of emotion, is simply negligible; and the novel of mental process, in this age of tottering faiths and insecure philosophies, is apt to be too painful to convey the pleasure which should be given by a work of art.
(Miss Louise Wilson, in the “North American Review.”)

div.head: Judicial "Humour"
div.p: To lighten the tedium of a dull case is not in itself culpable ambition, but it is one which ought to be very cautiously and discreetly indulged. A flash of the lambent with which illuminates alike the just and the unjust is always welcome, but it is not given to every one, or even to every Judge, to emit flashes of the rare quality. Laughter in Court, is very easily produced, but it must be confessed that the observations which call it forth do not always or even frequently impress those who do not breathe the judicial atmosphere. (“Times.”)

div.head: NOTES FROM SYRIA.
BEYROUT ELECTRIC TRAMWAYS.
CAIRO COMPANY INTERESTED.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Beyrout, June 18.

The Imperial Iradé sanctioning the concession for the electric tramways of Beyrout has at last been granted, and here is one of the many proofs of the great favour and influence that Negib Pacha Malhamé enjoys at Yildiz. The concession, as I have already mentioned, in a previous letter, has been sold for £10,000. The sum is out of all proportion to the financial importance of the scheme, the total cost of which is estimated at not more than six million francs, and the only way the liberality of the concession purchaser can be accounted for is the plausible conjecture that part of the sum is payable in shares.

So far the capital required has not been found, but it is said that the Barque de Paris et des Pays Bas is exerting itself in that direction. Most probably the Franco-Belgian Company, which has supplied the Electric Tramway Company of Damascus with the rolling stock and other material, will undertake the construction. Others believe that the Companie des Tramways du Caire may be undertaking the work.

div.head: Gas Versus Electricity.
div.p: The Gas Company of Beyrout, which, by virtue of its concession, has the pre-emption for the electric lighting of the town, will forfeit this right if, after three months' notice, it should not have decided to undertake the work, and in that case the new electric company will have both the right for locomotion and lighting exploitation. So far the official notice has not been given to the Gas Company, which is in no way likely to undertake the work, but which will try to make capital out of this pre-emptive right. The director of the Gas Company feels confident that however cheaply the electric company may be able to supply the lighting he can always underbid them. The big halls of the Beyrout houses require very strong light which the electric bulbs are too feeble to supply, and people prefer, on the other hand, a heating agency which can be advantagegously supplied by gas but not by electricity.

div.head: Benefits of Scheme.
div.p: The benefits accruing to the town of Beyrout from the execution of such a scheme are incalculable. Cheap, rapid, and a comfortable mode of locomotion is a public good too evident to be emphasized. Yet the town will benefit in other important directions. The principal streets where the tramway lines are to be laid will have necessarily to be solidly macadamized and well kept, and for their maintenance proper sewers will have to be constructed, and then the ruts and the dust and the nauseabond exhalations that offend sight and smell and all the senses generally, and which disfigure our main as well as our minor roads in a way such as cannot be seen even in a neglected village, will no more have their raison d'etre. The hygienic importance of the result cannot be overrated.

div.head: Beyrout's Streets
div.p: Some croaking pessimists are already talking of insuperable difficulties that the tramway will meet with in the shape of insufficient width of the streets. But barring a few spots where old buildings, relics of the old uncivilized municipal days (sic) which jut out with obtrusive ugliness, the streets where the lines are proposed to be laid are quite sufficient for the simultaneous circulation o the tramway and other traffic. To superficial observers our roads look too narrow, but no account seems to be taken of the considerable space occupied by the stalls of fruit and vegetable vendors who, through the laxity of interested connivance of municipal supervision, encroach on the public roads, making thereof so much shop room. These, however, will disappear as by magic if only the Municipality will exercise its legitimate authority, as it will have eventually to do if the tramway is, as we fondly hope, to become a "fait accompli." As regards the old buildings, these being few, the question of their demolition can be easily arranged on an equitable basis of expropriation.

div.head: Proposed Garden City
div.p: The rumour regarding the project of the Uzai prespective garden city is gaining wider publicity every day and with that more precision of detail. The Anglo-Egyptian Land ALlotmaent Company is said to have come to a preliminary agreement with Mr. Ibrahim J. Tabet, acting on his own behalf and that of his partners, about the vast Uzai lands. The terms of this agreement are thus roughly sketched. The Land Allotment will get the land at 20 paras per pic (drah.) and after allotting same according to the up-to-date real estate system and making liberal allowance for wide streets and spacious road points will fix the sale price at 3 piastres per pic. Then the company will also undertake the construction of houses according to plans devised by the would be proprietors, against the payment by the latter of 25% of the cost, the remaining 75% to be sunk during a period of 20 years, after which the complete ownership of the house will revert to the contracting party with the company.

div.head: Egyptian Company's Success.
div.p: The subject is being discussed in every quarter and by all classes, and if we are to judge the result of this scheme by the deep interest evinced therein by the inhabitants of Beyrout, the Land Allotment may from now be congratulated on an almost certain success. The project has such important bearings outside the domain of pure finance that it shoul dnot be wondered that it might have originated in the mind of the director of the Land Allotment Company, whos great financial schemes have always been characterised with high purpose, a progressive spirit, and a vast humanitarian scope of vision.

div.head: Deutsche Orient-Bank
div.p: I have it from an authoritative source that the Deutsche Orient Bank Aktiengesellschaft is about to establish a branch in beyrout next authumn, and that the directors of this branch are already appointed. Financiers must know that the Deutsche Orient Bank was founded with a capital of 16 million marks by the great German banking establishments, the Dresdner Bank, A. Schauffhausen scher Bankverein, and the Nationalbank für Deutschland. The expansion of German enterprise in Turkey does not seem to be confined to shipping and railway building. Indeed the establishment of banking concerns is a necessary corrolary of the fast development of German trade in Asiatic Turkey. The Imperial Ottoman Bank must view, this apparent encroachment with disfavour, the more so as it is alleged that the new German Bank will enjoy the patronage of the Turkish Government.

div.head: U.S.A. Consulate-General
div.p: Mr. Bergholtz, the United States Consul-General here, will leave shortly for Canton, China, and while he is to be congratulated on this transfer, which impilies a promotion, his friends will miss in him an affable host and in Mrs. Bergholtz a charming hostess.

div.head: GORDON RELIC TO BE SOLD.
div.p: An interesting relic of the siege of Khartoum and of the closing days of General Gordon has been sold in a London suction room. This is an officer's gilt star - one of many similar decorations which Gordon himself struck in order to revive the drooping spirits of the garrison. The medal, which was very rudely fashioned, was issued in several metals - the pewter was distributed pretty generally among the civil population but the gilt star is very rare. One of these primitive rewards was on view at the exhibition of Gordon relics, held in White hall a few years ago.

div.head: ARABIAN RELIGION BEFORE MOHAMED.
div.p: It is well known that previous to the era of Mohamed and the writing of the Koran, the religion of the Arabs around MEcca and Medina, and indeed wherever they roamed, was polytheistic, and that they worshipped numerous deities of both sexes.

In promulgating his montheistic religion the Prophet neccessarily denounced all other gods than Allah, and being anti-feministic in his theology, though hardly so in his actions, Mohamed specially warns his followers against female deities. Among those anathematised in Chapter 53 of the Koran are three known as Al'Lat, Al'Ouzza, ana Manat.
Of these, Al'Lat in the old pagan pantheon was the feminine counterpart of Allah; and Manat is of Maui (Destiny); whilst Al'Ouzza is that of Al'Aziz (Powerful).

The two first have frequently been found alluded to in ancient Arabian inscriptions, but not so Al'Ouzza in any very direct manner. A Yemenite, or Himyaritic, monumenta text recently presented to the Louvre, however, clearly mentions Al'Ouzza. Its date is about A.D. 350. The inscription relates the consecration of a memorial to the goddess 'Ouzza as a favour of her devotees, the dedicator of the monument and his daughter.

These 'Ouzza worshippers were therefore two persons who adored one of those goddesses of whom Mohamed said, "They are nothing more than names given by yourselves, you and your ancestors, without Allah ever having bestowed on them a particle of power."

div.head: FREIGHT WAR AND THE SUEZ DUES.
div.p: In reference to the shipping freight war which has been proceeding for some time between the Peninsular and Oriental and British India lines on the one hand and the Hansa Steamship Company on the other, a Bremen correspondent of the Berlin "Böreen Courier" states that the manager of the German company is reported to have again left for London in order to bring to an end the negotiations for the conclusion of the rate war. It is expected in Bremen that a definite settlement of the contest will be arrived at, as both aprties are said to desire the termination of the costly fight. The trade of the Hansa Company is so brisk that it is unable to cope with it by the use of its own steamers, and has been compelled to charter thirteen vessels. In the outward trade to India the correspondent states that the Hansa Company has scarcely suffered, as all its ships are fully loaded and a freight rate of 15s per ton is obtained, whereas the British competition has reduced rate to 5% per ton. The reduction of the Suez Canal dues is also of advantage to the German Company. There is again a lot of talk regarding the establishment of a community of interests with the Hamburg American Company, although little credence is attached to these reports in Bremen.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny.
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres reste toujours invarié à 3 1/4 pour cent.

Hier, an Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de non moins de 5/8 de livre à 80 1/8. L’Unifiée est restée invariée à 104 3/4, de même que la National Bank à 25 5/8, la Daira à 17 1/8 et la Delta Light à 12.
A Paris, l’action Crédit Fonciér Egyptien a perdu 1 franc à 771. La Banque d’Athène est demeurée inchangée à 154.
Ici, le marché des valeurs a été, aujourd'hui, moins animé, moins actif qu’hier. Toutefois, les dispositions ne sont pas mauvaises, bien que la fermeté ne se soit pas maintenue sur toute la ligne.

Pen d’afiaireè en National Bank, qui à couturé à 25 1/2-9/16. L’Agricolé s’est tenue à son prix d’hier, soit 9 11/16. La Cassa di Sconto s’est alourdie à 213 l’action ancienne, ainsi que la Banque d’Athènes à 154 et la Banque d’Orient à 131 1/2.
L’action Crédit Foncier a molli à 770 et là part de fondateur à 910.
L’action Immobilière a fléchi à 366, l’Entreprise and Development à 11 15/16 et l’Agricole du Nil à 259; la part de fondateur a progressé, par contre, à 7 1/16.
Bonne demande en Improvements Corporation, qui a gagné 1/8 à 4 11/16 3/4.
L’action Entreprises Immobilière et Tra-vâux a’est raffermie à 4 1/16; la part de fondateur, très recherchée, a avancé à 70.
L’action Wardan Estate s’est inscrite à 6 et la,Nile Land à 13 1/2.
La part de fondateur Land Allotment a encore faibli à 110.
L’action de capital Eaux du Caire a fait 120-121; les Jouissances ont clôturé à 261 1/2 après avoir atteint 264.

Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich, délaissés, sont restés à 15 7/16 l’action anciene, et 15 3/8 la nouvelle. Les Baehler ont débuté à 5 23/32 pour finir à 5 21/32 11/16. Lee National ont progressé à 3 3/8.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été' ramenés à 3 13/16 et les Glymenopoulo à 1 9/16.
Nous détachons d’une lettre de Londres, en date du 19 Juin, les lignes suivantes concernant la situation monétaire:

"Les conditions de l’argent se sont avanta-geaiement modifiées. L’encaisse de la Banque d’Angleterre s’est considérablement accru et la proportion de la réserve s’est élevée à plus de 47%. Le taux de l’escompte libre oscille entre 8 3/8 et 3 1/4 pour cent. La situation est donc, sans conteste, meilleure, bien que les disponibilités du marché aient à faire face à l'emprunt irlandais, annoncé pour le 7 Juillet; là tenue du cours du Consolidé anglais en est affectée. Le “Statist” ne prévoit pas une augmentation prochaine des disponibilités et s’attend même à des sorties considérables poor la fin du mois courant.

Le Stock Exchange jouit en ce moment d’un repos relatif; c'est l’effet de la morte saison. Là clientèle est devenue rare, et les mouvements des valeurs quelque peu somnolentes ont beaucoup perdu de leur étendue."
On annonce d’Athènes que L’assemblée générale extraordinaire des actionnaires de la Banque du Crédit Industriel de Grèce, tenue samedi passé, a voté à l’unanimité la fusion avec la Banque d’Athènes.
L’assemblée extraordinaire de la Banque d’Athènes, qui doit statuer sur le même objet; est fixée comme on sait; au samedi 7 Juillet prochain.

On assure que l’arrangement négocié entre le gouvernement et la Société des Sucreries et Raffinerie d’Egyptè concernant l’achat par l’Etat des lignes de railways à voie étroite de cet té Société serait sur le point d’être conclu, au prix d’environ LE. 350,000.

Au dire d’un journal d’Alexandrie, un groupe financier, à la tête daquel se trouverait M. Scott, ancien directeur de la Compagnie d’assurance "The Gresham," se propose de former une Société anonyme de constructions economiques dont le siege social serait au Caire:

"Les acheteurs-locataires deviendraient pro priétaires au bout d’un certain nombrè d’années en payant un loyer comprenant l’amortis sement du prix de l’immeuble et une prime d’assurance, de sorte qu’en cas de mort leurs héritiers deviendraient par le fait propriétaires.”

div.head: THE BODMIN PETITION.
Mr. Agar Robartes Unseated
Mr. Justice Grantham and The Government
div.p: The Bodmin election petition trial was conluded on the 18th inst. The Judges found that the election was void on the ground of corrupt treating, and declared Mr. Agar-Robartes unseated, Counsel's speeches being concluded.

The Judges retired a few minutes after four o'clock, and after an interval returned into court. Mr. Justice Graham read a long statement regarding charges brought against himself. After remarking that what had recently happened owing to findings of his own had justified in a remarkable way, the refusal of the late Lord Chief Justcie Cockburn to be a party to appointing Judges of the High Court to try election petitions on the ground that he would be made the subject of attack by bitter politicians, Mr. Justice Grantham, his voice broken, by his emotion, proceeded:-

"As everyone in this court and in this country knows, a notice of motion has been made in the House of Commons accusing me of partisanship in the Yarmouth petition. A majority of the members of the House have identified themselves with the motion. It is idle for me, therefore, in giving my judgment now to disguise from myself the fact which makes a delivery of this judgment one of the most painful duties of my life. I cannot but feel that a charge of the greatest gravity is haning over my head, which, if true, would have made me unfit to try this petition, or to deliver this judgment and would justify anyone and everyone adversely affected by it in saying it is the judgment of an unjust Judge. I have been unfairly treated by the Government, which has allowed me to proceed with such an important trial before this charge had either been proved or withdrawn. As far as I know, the charge is absolutely without foundation. No evidence upon which it is based has been suggested that I am aware of though the mother of lies has taken advantage of the opportunity which has been given her to fructify lavishly ard spread her offspring all over the land. So I gather from the numerous letters and newspapers sent to me.

"Simultaneously with the making of this charge I find that a gathering of Liberal agents on the occasion of the annual meeting of the National Liberal Federation (2,000 delegates met from 400 constituencies), after they had appointed Lord Tweedmouth their president, adopted a resolution expressing dissatisfaction at a grave miscarriage of justice in connection with the petitions at Yarmouth and Maidstone, and urged the Government to amend the Constitution of the election courts. Is it just to the judges of England that such charges should be made and no effort made to prove or disprove them at the earliest possible moment? The judges are powerless to defend themselves at all times in the House of Commons, at whose special request they are discharging these most difficult duties. They have a right to expect protection if not defence. Their judicial lives and character are not their own. Let it not be thought I complain of the 300 who signed the petition to the Prime Minister. They might not have had a friendly motive to me, but I attribute no motive. What I insist on is that before they petitioned I had demanded of the Prime Minister that the mover of the notice should be called upon to prove his charge. My answer was, and is, that the written judgments in the previous petitions were placed in the hands of the Government at the time they were delivered, and the Government could have said at once whether there was any foundation for that charge.

"The only answer I have had given to me is that it was not intended to allow the matter to be brought forward until my judgment had been given in the Bodmin case. Again I assign no motive, but allow others to draw their own inference. When a few days ago I was officially informed that it was the intention of the government to have another postponement for three weeks I could stand it no longer, and felt obliged to find a safety valve in speech. If similar charges should be made in future against me or any of my brothers I trust different treatment may be meted out to us."

Mr. Justice Grantham then reviewed the circumstances of the Bodmin case, prefacing his remarks by stating that he differed from his learned brother on one point-as to what were expenses for the purposes of an election, and as to when a contest actually began. His Lordship's general conclusions were that in regard to Mr. Robartes's ownacts of treating it woul dbe hard to treat him as an old electioneerer, but that MR. Millman's (agent) acts of treating alone and the treating at the Lanhydrock garden party were sufficient to vitiate the election. There could be no doubt that Lanhydrock was corrupt treating, though Lord and Lady Clifden might have been guilty of treating without doing anything intentionally immoral or dishonest, "My judgment is clear," Mr. Justice Grantham added, "that seat cannot be held and that Mr. Robartes must be unseated."
Mr. Justice Laurance concurred.

The two Judges were hooted as they left the court, but they merely smiled and bowed. The Unionist agent, Mr. Snell, was greeted with considerable hooting, and had to be escorted to his hotel by a strong bodyguard of police.

div.head: FOOD SUPPLY IN WAR.
BRITISH FLEETS ON THE DEFENCE.
div.p: In the final maneuvres of the British Fleets, which are to take place this week, the naval correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph" writes, a rather smaller naval force will be employed than cooperated in the early operations, as a number of obsolescent ships which were raised to war complement to test the mobilisation arrangements at the home ports have now been demobilised, together with a number of torpedo craft, while the cruisers Juno and Talbot have been detached to act as escort to the Prince and Princess of Wales on their voyage to Norway for the coronation of King Haakon and Queen Maud. With these exceptions, every efficient ship in home waters and in the Mediterranean will be assisting in the scheme which has been specially designed to test the efficiency of the British Fleet for the defence of commerce. As the scheme of British naval defence is based on the two-power standard- that is, the equality of the British Fleet with a combination of the two next strongest navies in Europe, with a margin over to provide for contingencies - the naval forces which are to be opposed to each other in the comming maneuvres have been distributed so as to give the Red British - Admiral a great superiority of strength.

The Red Fleet has England as its "territory," with GIbraltar as a distant base, at which the Mediterranean Fleet is stationed, while the Blue Fleet has as its "country". Ireland and Scotland and the Channel Islands, with Lagos, on the Portuguese coast, as a distand base. How Blue will attack British commerce depends, of course, entirely on the plans elaborated by Vice Admiral Sir W.H. May, the Commander-in-Chief, but it is anticipated that the main burden of the guerre de course will devolve upon Prince Louis of Battenberg, who commands the Second Crusader Squadron, and has shown himself a most original and dashing naval leader. On the other hand, it may be accepted, without question, that nothing will be wanting in the scheme of defence of Admiral Sir Arthur Wilson and his colleagues.

One of the advantages of these operations is that an unusually large number of flag officers are to be employed, and will thus gain experience of the greatest possible value. The following is a full list of the Admirals and their flagships:

The attack on commerce will take place over a very large area, which embraces a part of the ocean which is most frequented by British merchant ships, and it is here, as they draw in towards the British Isles, that they are most open to attack by an enemy. The Admiralty have announced that it is proposed to include in the scheme as many as possible of the slow steamers outward bound via the Mediterranean Sea and South Atlantic, and steamers homeward bound via the Mediterranean, but steamers carrying mails, passengers (Excepting where the conditions of teh passengers' tickets authorise the vessels cooperating in the maneuvres), live stock, chilled meats, green fruit or vegetables, have not been asked to take part. Cooperating vessels will conform to the following conditions:

1. They will call at Falmouth or Milford HAven if outward bound, and at Gibraltar is homeward bound, and make their passages thence in company with other vessels or otherwise, as may be directed by the senior naval officer in these ports. It is proposed that as vessels collect in the above ports they should be dispatched along the trade routes in groups of twelve or less, and it is anticipated that vessels will not be delayed on their voyage for more than sixty hours.

2. At each port the masters of vessels will receive full instructions concerning the future conduct of their ships and the order in which their groups will sail. They will be required to conform to these instructions and to obey signals made to them.
3. Whilst cooperating they will fly a red ensign at the fore, the enemy's men-of-war being distinguised by a blue ensign on the triatic stay abaft the foremast.
4. They will be required to do their best to escape from the enemy and to communicate any information they may possess to men-of-war of their own side.

5. Should an enemy's man of war approach within three miles by day or one mile by night of a vessel, fire three guns and hoist a signal to stop, the vessel will be considered captured and will stop and allow herself to be borded. After capture, a vessel will communicate no information to either side.
6. Cooperation will be considered as having ceased, and a vessel will haul down the red ensign, be free to part company, and shall proceed on her voyage.

(a.) On passing the line between the Tuskar and Small Lights if bound up the Irish Channel, the line through the Smalls and Lundy Island Lights if bound up the Bristol Channel; the line between the Lizard and Ushant if bound up the English Channel; the meridian of Cape Spartel if bound for the Mediterranean; and the latitude of Cape St. Vincent if bound for the South Atlanta.
(b.) After having been captured and boarded.
(c.) At noon on July 2.

It will be readily understood that with about 300 men-of-war, including torpedo-boats and submarines, engaged, and with a larger number of merchant ships cooperating, these operatinos will be of extraordinary interest.

div.head: FAUNA OF THE EMPIRE.
div.p: A deputation, headed by Lord Curzon of Kedleston and including the Duchess of Bedford, Lord Monk Bretton, Sir Edward Tennant, Captain the Hon. Guy Baring, Sir H. Seton Karr and Sir William Lee Warner, waited upon Lord Elgin at the Colonial Office last week and presented, on behalf of the Society for the Preservation of the Wild Fauna of the Empire, certain recommendations for the protection of various species of wild animals which appeared to be in danger of extinction.

The recommendations were drawn up as the result of reports called for from the various Colonies and African Protectorates by Lord Elgin's predecessor in office, Mr. Lyttelton, on representations being made to him by the society last year. They are:- (1) That the returns of all game animals killed should continue to be included in the annual reports of each Protectorate or Colony. To them should be added statements showing the receipts from all sources connected with the preservation of game, such as licences, fines, etc., (2.) That a map should be prepared showing the present game reserves in Africa; (3.) that the sale of hides, horns, etc., of game animals in the British dominions in Africa and at Aden should be prohibited; (4.) that the sale of elephant tusks weighing less than 25 lbs. should be prohibited and the tusks confiscated; (5.) that no shooting whatsoever, except for administrative reasons, should be permitted in a reserve; and (6.) that a strict return of all game killed should be made annually by every license-holder.

Speeches were made by Lord Curzon, Sir H. Seton-Karr, Mr. E.N. Buxton, Mr. S.H. Whitbread, M.P., and Mr. F. Gillett in explaining their views with regard to reserves and their management. It was pointed out that the society fully realized that the interests of the preservation of wild animals could not be allowed to conflict with the development and occupation of British Africa, and that it was no part of their programme to preserve the larger carnivora or dangerous animals in proximity to settled districts. But the speakers were strongly impressed with the imminent danger of extinction of a number of rare and beautiful species in Africa, and felt that they had a duty to perform in urging the Government do take adequate steps, before it was too late, to presserve for posterity the fauna of the Empire. The formation was advocated of definited reserves within which all animals might find a sanctuary and breeding place of sufficient size to cover their annual migrations, and it was stated that several such sanctuaries were already in existence and had given evidence of the valuable protection they had afforded. It was emphasized that such sanctuaries could not be effected without adequate supervision, and that they should not be sanctuaries in name only, but afford real security from molestation.
There was an exchange of views on various matters of detail, and Lord Elgin throughout was most sympathetic and promised to give the recommendations of the society his careful consideration.
Mr. E.N. Buxton expressed the deputation's appreciation of their reception, and the proceedings then terminated.

div.head: ZION.
div.p: The horrible history of Bielostok has furnished Mr. Israel Zangwill with a new text for preaching the urgency of the Zionist Territorial Scheme. We are heartily with him in his aspirations. Here, on the one hand, is a land in which, whenever political differences become acute, the Jews are massacred on all hands; here, on another, is an empire unable to fill its waste spaces, which is tolerant to the extreme in all religious matters, and which has an unrivalled capaity for assimmilating all races under its rule; here, in the third place, are some millions (perhaps) of people ready to occupy one of its waste spaces under conditions of autonomy, with the money available for giving the settlers a fair economic start. Why does not the British Government exercise imagination, and make an experiment by which of nothing can be lost, though much may be gained? Whatever we may feel about the Jews, there is no gainsaying the fact that they are a race to be trusted, and that, if they make a bargain, they will not forswear it, "though it were to their own hindrance." Mr. Zangwill and others are responsible for the idea that a new Jerusalem can be founded outside Palestine. We may have our own opinion upon that subject; but the responsibility is his, and there is no reason why we should refuse him the opportunity of making the experiment.

div.head: THE TIGRIS REVOLT>
OFFICIAL STATEMENT.
div.p: The Imperial Ottoman Embassy in London have issued the following statement for publication:-

Several London papers of the 5th inst. have published a telegram from Bushire reporting that Arab tribes of the Tigris, who were described as being in revolt against the Imperial authority, fired on a British steamer, which was on her way from Baghdad to Basra, many bullets piercing the sides of the vessel, and that the Ottoman authorities were quite powerless to suppress the rising, owing to the scarcity of troops. The facts are not as reported. What really occurred amounts to this - some tribes fired a few shots, and the Imperial authorities, on hearing of the incident, sent an adequate number of troops at once to the spot and took necessary steps for the arrest and exemplary punishment of the guilty men.

div.head: THE SYRIA-OTTOMAN RAILWAY SCHEME.
div.p: Before Mr. Justice Bigham, sitting as Bankruptcy Judge, in the King's Bench Division, last week, Mr. Lusk, K.C., asked for a declaration that Madame Katharina de Kohnle was entitles to the benefit of a proof of debt for £14,121 dodged against Mr. J.R. Pilling's estate by Mr. David Chapman in 1898. Counsel explaind that Mr. Pilling obtained from Elias Effendi in 1890 a concession from the Turkish Government for the construction of a line of railway from Acre to Damascus and was indebted to him in respect of the purchase rights of his (Pilling's) interest in a sum of about £60,000. In May 1894, Elias assigned his rights and interest in the concession to Mr. Chapman, who brought an action against Pilling, and in 1896 obtained a judgment for £14,121. Mr. Elias subsequently alleged that there had been a total failure of the consideration as between Mr. Chapman and hiimself, and in 1905 he assigned to MAdame de Kohnle, who had provided a lot of money in connection with the scheme, all his rights in respect of the judgment debt for which Mr. Chapman's proof had been admitted.- His Lordship said the legal holder of the judgment debt was Mr. Chapman, who might at any time be called upon to answer for the charges given upon the debt, and he could not substitute. Madame de Kohnle for Mr. Chapman.-The motion was accordingly dismissed, with costs.

div.head: INCREASE IN BASE COINAGE.
div.p: Some curious facts are disclosed in a return issued by the Home Office, showing the working of the regulations made in 1886 for carrying out the Prosecution of Offences Acts, 1879 and 1884, with statistics setting forth the number, nature, result, and cost of the proceedings instituted by the director in accordance with those regulations, from the 1st day of January 1905 to the 31st day of December 1905. In appears that all prosecutions in England and Wales for offences under 24 and 25 Vict. cap 99 (Coinage Offences Act, 1861) are conducted by the director. The particulars of such prosecutions in 1905 show that there were 201 persons arrested for coinage offences, 130 being in London. The report says: - "The serious increase in the number of offences against His Majesty's Mint noticed in last year's return has steadily continued during the period covered by the present one, and the number of persons proceeded against in 1905 was nearly three times as many, as 1902. Of the 53 persons convicted of coinage offences. Of the total of 122 convictions in 1905, 53 were for felony, and of these 21 were for making counterfeit coin, 14 for possessing moulds or other implements for its manufacture; and three for gilding and selling coin. It is a significant and disquieting fact that 35 makers of counterfeit coin or possessors of moulds and tools for coining were convicted for the first time. The number of pieces of base coin seized or found in connection with the coinage prosecutions for the yeaer was 1,176."

div.head: MR. CHOATE AND BISHOP POTTER.
div.p: Mr. Choate, in an interview, has taken exception to Bishop Potter's pessimistic view of English professions of friendship for Americans. He declared that the mutual respect and affection with which British and Americans regard each other could not be dissipated by such incidents as the recent commercial scandals. He regretted certain aspects of these scandals because he felt that sensational journalism magnified the real condition of things.

div.head: MACEDONIAN FINANCES.
DEFICIT TO BE MADE GOOD BY TURKEY.
div.p: Replying to a question in the House of Commons last week, Sir E. Grey said the Turkish Government have undertaken to make good any deficit in the MAcedonian budget out of Imperial revenues generally. If the increased Customs duties are devoted to this purpose the deficit to be made good from other revenues will protanto be diminished.
The proceeds of the increase of 3 percent in the Customs duties will, if the increase is agreed to be applicable to the Macedonian Budget as a whole, of which the military expenditure forms a part.

His Majesty's Government have no control over Turkish revenues, the allocation of which has not formed the subject of any agreement between the two Governments. But it is estimated that the increased Customs duties will fall considerably short of what is required to make up the deficit in the Macedonian vilayets, and, in view of the difficulty which already exists in meeting this it cannot be assumed that, if assistance is given, large sources of Turkish revenue will automatically be set free for other purposes.

div.head: GERMANY AND ABYSSINIA.
div.p: With reference to the Press articles emanating from British, Italian, and French sources stating that Germany intends taking political action in Abyssinia, the "Kolnische Zeitung" is informed on good authority that Kommerzienrat Bosch sent an expedition consisting of agricultural instructors, architects, a merchant, a lady teacher, a house keeper, a midwife, a locksmith, a wheelwright, a carpenter and a painter to Abyssinia towards the end of March solely fore educational purposes.
The German Government is in no way connected with this enterprise, which is of an entirely private character, and political motives play no part whatever in it.

div.head: OSTRICH FEATHER SALES.
div.p: These sales commenced in London on the 4th inst. and concluded on the 8th. They comprised 4,387 cases Cape, 7 cases from Australia, and 78 cases Egyptian of which about 4.325 cases. Cape, 6 cases from Australia and 61 cases Egyptian sold.
The weight of feathers offered was 81,000 lb. against 77,400 lb. in April last.

There was a good demand gnerally, but owing to bigger supply competition was scarcely so keen as at the previous suctions. Wing feathers, of which there was an exceptionally good and large selection, sold principally at a decline of about 10 percent which, however, was not always marked on the better qualities. The decline was most noticeable on defective and broken which were 10 to 15 percent lower. White declined on the average about 10 percent, broken and defective being 10 to 15 percent lower. White and light femina sold the same as white. Dark femina rather lower. Byocks on the whole steady to rather lower. Spadonas were scarce and very firm. White boos were irregular, being steady to 5 percent lower. Femina boos and drab boos rather easier, except light femina which were full up. Black butts unchanged. Long and medium drab especially good lines firm, medium and medium and short steady. FLoss, irregular, steady to 10 percent decline on short.
Egyptian: Only a small quantity of unimportant parcels catalogued, of which part sold at above changes.
The quantity sold realised £191,000.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE "Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the “Egyptian Gazette” is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd’s mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt. For abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For further particulars apply to the Manager "Egyptian Gazette.
A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
